rsbNotes.title: Josh 13–21
rsbNotes.text: 13:1–21:45 The third major section of the book details the division of the land among the tribes. The significance of these chapters is made explicit in 21:43–45. The lists of boundaries and towns represent the objective content of the promises of God. Although many of the places are no longer known, and although their allotment here did not in all cases mean that the designated tribe actually occupied them (23:13), they nevertheless are an elaborate testimony to the faithfulness of the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 19:1
rsbNotes.text: 19:1 in the midst . . . Judah. Simeon’s allotment was inside the territory of Judah (Gen. 49:7). Judah and Simeon acted together in Judg. 1:3, 17. At some stage the tribe of Simeon seems to have lost its distinct identity.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 19:8–9
rsbNotes.text: 19:8, 9 inheritance. See note 1:6.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 19:15
rsbNotes.text: 19:15 twelve. It is not clear which twelve cities are meant.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 19:30
rsbNotes.text: 19:30 twenty-two. There are more than twenty-two towns mentioned, but some may be noted as points on the boundary.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 19:38
rsbNotes.text: 19:38 nineteen. The list apparently is incomplete.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 19:47
rsbNotes.text: 19:47 Dan. A fuller account of Dan and their conquest of Leshem is given in Judg. 18.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 19:49–50
rsbNotes.text: 19:49, 50 See notes 14:6–15.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 19:50
rsbNotes.text:
19:50 By command of the Lord. This divine command is not recorded elsewhere (cf. 14:9 note). See Num. 14:30.

Timnath-serah. Joshua would be buried here (24:30).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 19:51
rsbNotes.text:
19:51 Eleazar. See note 14:1.

Shiloh. See note 18:1.

before the Lord. See note 18:6.

tent of meeting. See note 18:1.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 20
rsbNotes.text: 20:1–9 The record of the division of the land is followed by a provision for basic justice in it, illustrating God’s concern for justice and the preservation of life. The provision implies the idea of just retribution, while restraining the injustice that could flow from vengeance (Deut. 4:41–43).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 20:2
rsbNotes.text:
20:2 cities of refuge. These were places where certain offenders could escape unjust vengeance and seek a fair trial. Similar cities will also be given to the Levites (21:1–42; Num. 35:6), and by implication will be places where the law of God can be found.

through Moses. See Ex. 21:12–14; Num. 35:6–34; Deut. 19:1–13.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 20:3
rsbNotes.text:
20:3 without intent or unknowingly. Unintentional sin receives specific treatment in the law (Lev. 4:2, 13, 22, 27; 5:15, 18; Num. 15:22–29; 35:22; Deut. 4:42; 19:4; Ezek. 45:20; cf. Heb. 9:7).

avenger of blood. This would be the victim’s nearest male relative or possibly an official of the city where the killing occurred (Num. 35:19–21).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 20:4
rsbNotes.text:
20:4 the gate of the city. This was the usual place for legal transactions (Ruth 4:1–12).

elders. Apparently the elders held a preliminary hearing of the accused man’s case.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 20:5
rsbNotes.text: 20:5 they shall not give up. There is a presumption in favor of the accused.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 20:6
rsbNotes.text: 20:6 death of . . . high priest. His death marked the end of an era and provided a convenient limitation to the provisions made here.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 20:7
rsbNotes.text: 20:7 set apart. The Hebrew verb can also be translated “sanctified.”

rsbNotes.title: Josh 20:8
rsbNotes.text: 20:8 beyond. See Deut. 4:41–43.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 20:9
rsbNotes.text: 20:9 the stranger. Concern for the foreigner in Israel was a regular feature of the law (e.g., Ex. 12:48–49; 20:10; 22:21; 23:9, 12).
